main_point: The professor explains Varnish layers and conservation ethics and how to interpret evidence when measurements can be misleading.
detail1: The professor distinguishes conservation (a process) from curation (a proxy/measurement).
detail2: He suggests testing an asymmetric prediction involving authenticity and craquelure.
attitude: Casual but analytical; he warns against over-trusting a neat correlation.
organization_point: He adds a tangent about a conference anecdote to show real-world constraints.
connecting_point: The example about controlling for varnish shows how bias can flip an apparent pattern.
